title: Acid-Base Titration Simulator
instructions: Simulate a titration of 25.00 mL of 0.100 mol/L NaOH with 0.100 mol/L HCl. Track the pH as HCl is added from a burette. Record the volume at the equivalence point and sketch the titration curve.
steps: Set up: 25.00 mL of 0.100 mol/L NaOH in a conical flask with 3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator (pink in base).
Fill burette with 0.100 mol/L HCl. Record the initial volume.
Add HCl in 1 mL increments, swirling and recording pH after each addition.
Near the equivalence point, add HCl drop-by-drop. Note the colour change from pink to colourless.
Record the exact volume of HCl at the equivalence point. Plot pH vs volume of HCl added.
Calculate: moles HCl at equivalence point = moles NaOH. Verify concentration of NaOH.
expected_outcome: The titration curve shows a sigmoid shape with a sharp jump at pH 7 (equivalence point). Volume of HCl at equivalence point = 25.00 mL. The indicator changes from pink to colourless at the endpoint.
